title: rust polars 0.28.0
doc(python): Add reference to regex crate to docs
fix(rust, python): fill null list
body: fixes #7828

title: fix(python): Add missing type hint for `is_between`
body:
I tried to use `is_between` on a duration column with timedelta inputs, and `mypy` complained. Simply a missing type hint. I replaced the type hint with `IntoExpr`, as it's parsed into expressions.

While doing so, I noticed two things about this method:

* Series and Expr handle the inputs differently. For Series, strings are parsed as literals, while for Expr, strings are parsed as column names. I think we should be consistent here: if we accept Expr input, we should parse strings as column names. We could also decide not to support Expr input here for Series.is_between, as it doesn't make much sense to me anyway.
* The argument names `start` and `end` only make sense when using this on temporal data. I would prefer `lower_bound` and `upper_bound` as argument names.

title: docs(python): update concat docstring for how parameter
perf(rust, python): fix hashing regression
fix(rust, python): fix explode list[null]
body: fixes #7829

title: feat(python): allow Series init with `Unknown` dtype to proceed as if dtype is `None`, to allow inference

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body:
The `Unknown` dtype isn't invalid, it's just... "unknown". So, this PR allows for  inference if a `Series` is declared as having `Unknown` dtype at init time; this is equivalent to dtype=None, and is also consistent with the the way that PyDataFrame `read_rows` and `read_dicts` schema overrides behave.

#### Also:

* Added missing imports that were declared in `polars.datatypes.__init__.__all__`, but that weren't actually being imported at that level.

* Reinstated `venv` into gitignore for the time-being; otherwise ~18,000 files show up as unversioned and `typos` goes bananas on `pre-commit` (spraying megabytes of text into your terminal) if you haven't both created the new/preferred `.venv` _and_ deleted the old `venv`. Will smooth things over until everyone has transitioned.

title: perf(rust, python): rechunk dataframe before unique computation
body:
#7774

The runtime is dominated by `index_to_chunk_index`. This runtime grows linear with the number of chunks. We could implement this better with binary search. Can explore this later.

title: perf(rust, python): improve hash quality
body: Use ahash but inline some state to reduce operations in `vec_hash`. This prevents terrible perf on large integers. On small integers we are a bit slower.

title: feat(python): Improve automatic output dtype setting for `map_dict`.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body:
Improve automatic output dtype setting for `map_dict`:
  - Added `dtype` option to specify output dtype if automatic output dtype setting is not correct.
  - If no output dtype is specified:
    - Set to same dtype as expression specified as default value: e.g. `default=pl.first()` or `default=pl.col("c")`
    - If the default value was not an expression, try to convert mapping values first to the same dtype as the input column. If that fails, just convert the mapping values to a normal Series.

Closes: #7788

title: chore(python): fixup stacklevels

labels.name: chore
labels.description: Maintenance work that does not impact the user

body:
closes #7795 

Demo:

with the latest release:
```python
In [7]: data = [{"a": 1, "b": 4}, {"a": 2, "b": 5}, {"a": 3, "b": 6}]
   ...: df = pl.from_dicts(dicts=data)

In [8]: import pandas as pd
   ...: pd_df = pd.DataFrame([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]], columns=["a", "b", "c"])
   ...: df = pl.from_pandas(pd_df, nan_to_none=True)
   ...:
```

Here:
```python
In [1]: data = [{"a": 1, "b": 4}, {"a": 2, "b": 5}, {"a": 3, "b": 6}]
   ...: df = pl.from_dicts(dicts=data)
<ipython-input-1-78a761bb55c8>:2: DeprecationWarning: `dicts` is deprecated as an argument to `from_dicts`; use `data` instead.
  df = pl.from_dicts(dicts=data)

In [2]: import pandas as pd
   ...: pd_df = pd.DataFrame([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]], columns=["a", "b", "c"])
   ...: df = pl.from_pandas(pd_df, nan_to_none=True)
<ipython-input-2-6984e8025b58>:3: DeprecationWarning: `nan_to_none` is deprecated as an argument to `from_pandas`; use `nan_to_null` instead.
  df = pl.from_pandas(pd_df, nan_to_none=True)
```

Likewise, for the example from the issue:
```python
In [1]: df = pl.DataFrame({'a': [1,2], 'b': [1,2]})
   ...: df.with_columns(pl.col('a').sort(True))
<ipython-input-1-da82a41e8139>:2: DeprecationWarning: All arguments of Expr.sort will be keyword-only in the next breaking release. Use keyword arguments to silence this warning.
  df.with_columns(pl.col('a').sort(True))
Out[1]: 
shape: (2, 2)
┌─────┬─────┐
│ a   ┆ b   │
│ --- ┆ --- │
│ i64 ┆ i64 │
╞═════╪═════╡
│ 2   ┆ 1   │
│ 1   ┆ 2   │
└─────┴─────┘
```

title: docs(python): Improve pl.when documentation
body:
Inspired by #7725 

- clarify behaviour chained when-thens
- note that otherwise is optional

The See-Also section does not really work well, see the ref page here: https://pola-rs.github.io/polars/py-polars/html/reference/expressions/api/polars.when.html#polars.when

Because we do not explicitly expose the `WhenThen` and `WhenThenThen` objects. Should we just remove that, and simply focus on documenting everything through `pl.when`? That would be my preference.

title: chore(python): add a `make requirements` option to install/refresh dependencies without having to recreate the `venv`

labels.name: chore
labels.description: Maintenance work that does not impact the user

body:
Inspired by a Discord [thread](https://discord.com/channels/908022250106667068/908022461751234570/1089265752550416385), I've added...
```
make requirements
```
...which will update/install everything listed in our various `requirements` files _without_ having to delete/recreate the associated `venv`. Slightly less friction staying up to date as dependencies advance.

title: chore(python): Drop `ruff` target version

labels.name: chore
labels.description: Maintenance work that does not impact the user

body:
`ruff` autodetects its target version from our package specification `requires-python = ">=3.7` - no need to specify it in the ruff config.

Also bumped to the latest version.

title: chore(python): Rename `venv` folder to `.venv`

labels.name: chore
labels.description: Maintenance work that does not impact the user

body:
Triggered by #7782

I actually wanted to make this change a while ago. The naming of the venv folder does not matter much, but I think `.venv` is a bit nicer than simply `venv` for a few reasons, explained well in [PEP 704](https://peps.python.org/pep-0704/#use-a-different-name-for-the-virtual-environment-directory):

> The name .venv was picked since it:
>
> * does not conflict with any valid Python import name
> * does not conflict venv module in the standard library
> * has pre-existing usage in the Python community
> * has support for auto-detection in common text editors
> * can be typed without modifier keys on common keyboard layouts

Now that `maturin` will offer some automatic support when using `.venv`, I think that's a valid reason for switching.

title: feat(python): new utility `from_repr` function that reconstructs a DataFrame from its table repr

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body:
Ref: #7732.

New productivity/utillity function `pl.from_repr`; allows us to reconstruct DataFrames from their table `repr`. 

* Primarily intended as a time-saver for dropping examples off StackOverflow (or the Discord) into the console where the original init/data wasn't posted, so we can get debugging with a minimum of effort ;)

* Handles all scalar types (inc. datetimes with timeunit/timezone, categorical, duration, etc), leading line-level comments / ellipsis / whitespace / prompt chars, wrapped table headers, empty tables, and truncated/omitted rows/cols. 

* The repr start/end is auto-detected so that you don't have to trim the input string into compliance, and the supported table formats are `UTF_FULL_CONDENSED` (our default) and `UTF8_FULL`, with/without the "rounded corners" modifier.

* Obvious limitation - it can't reconstruct what isn't there (missing cols, truncated data, etc).

* Will enhance (where possible) with basic support for nested types (List, Struct) later.

## Examples

**Empty:**
_(Still tracks the schema)_
```python
df = pl.from_repr(
    """
    Empty dataframe
    ┌─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬───────┐
    │ id  ┆ q1  ┆ q2  ┆ q3  ┆ q4  ┆ total │
    │ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ ---   │
    │ str ┆ i8  ┆ i16 ┆ i32 ┆ i64 ┆ f64   │
    ╞═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═══════╡
    └─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴───────┘
    """
)

df.rows()
# []

df.schema
# {
#     "id": pl.Utf8,
#     "q1": pl.Int8,
#     "q2": pl.Int16,
#     "q3": pl.Int32,
#     "q4": pl.Int64,
#     "total": pl.Float64,
# }
```
**Dates, nulls, commented-out:**
_(Truncated cols identified and omitted)_
```python
df = pl.from_repr(
    """
    # ┌────────────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬──────┐
    # │ dt         ┆ c1  ┆ c2  ┆ c3  ┆ ... ┆ c96 ┆ c97 ┆ c98 ┆ c99  │
    # │ ---        ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆     ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ ---  │
    # │ date       ┆ i32 ┆ i32 ┆ i32 ┆     ┆ i64 ┆ i64 ┆ i64 ┆ i64  │
    # ╞════════════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪══════╡
    # │ 2023-03-25 ┆ 1   ┆ 2   ┆ 3   ┆ ... ┆ 96  ┆ 97  ┆ 98  ┆ 99   │
    # │ 1999-12-31 ┆ 3   ┆ 6   ┆ 9   ┆ ... ┆ 288 ┆ 291 ┆ 294 ┆ null │
    # │ null       ┆ 9   ┆ 18  ┆ 27  ┆ ... ┆ 864 ┆ 873 ┆ 882 ┆ 891  │
    # └────────────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴──────┘
    """
)

df
# shape: (3, 8)
# ┌────────────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬─────┬──────┐
# │ dt         ┆ c1  ┆ c2  ┆ c3  ┆ c96 ┆ c97 ┆ c98 ┆ c99  │
# │ ---        ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ --- ┆ ---  │
# │ date       ┆ i32 ┆ i32 ┆ i32 ┆ i64 ┆ i64 ┆ i64 ┆ i64  │
# ╞════════════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪═════╪══════╡
# │ 2023-03-25 ┆ 1   ┆ 2   ┆ 3   ┆ 96  ┆ 97  ┆ 98  ┆ 99   │
# │ 1999-12-31 ┆ 3   ┆ 6   ┆ 9   ┆ 288 ┆ 291 ┆ 294 ┆ null │
# │ null       ┆ 9   ┆ 18  ┆ 27  ┆ 864 ┆ 873 ┆ 882 ┆ 891  │
# └────────────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴─────┴──────┘
```
**A bit of everything:**
_(Identify the table within the text, handle row dividers, wrapped headers, timezones, etc)_
```python
df = pl.from_repr(
    """
    In [2]: with pl.Config() as cfg:
       ...:     pl.Config.set_tbl_formatting("UTF8_FULL", rounded_corners=True)
       ...:     print(df)
       ...:
    shape: (1, 5)
    ╭───────────┬────────────┬───┬───────┬────────────────────────────────╮
    │ source_ac ┆ source_cha ┆ … ┆ ident ┆ timestamp                      │
    │ tor_id    ┆ nnel_id    ┆   ┆ ---   ┆ ---                            │
    │ ---       ┆ ---        ┆   ┆ str   ┆ datetime[μs, Asia/Tokyo]       │
    │ i32       ┆ i64        ┆   ┆       ┆                                │
    ╞═══════════╪════════════╪═══╪═══════╪════════════════════════════════╡
    │ 123456780 ┆ 9876543210 ┆ … ┆ a:b:c ┆ 2023-03-25 10:56:59.663053 JST │
    ├╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┤
    │ …         ┆ …          ┆ … ┆ …     ┆ …                              │
    ├╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┼╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌╌┤
    │ 803065983 ┆ 2055938745 ┆ … ┆ x:y:z ┆ 2023-03-25 12:38:18.050545 JST │
    ╰───────────┴────────────┴───┴───────┴────────────────────────────────╯
    """
)

df
# shape: (2, 4)
# ┌─────────────────┬───────────────────┬───────┬────────────────────────────────┐
# │ source_actor_id ┆ source_channel_id ┆ ident ┆ timestamp                      │
# │ ---             ┆ ---               ┆ ---   ┆ ---                            │
# │ i32             ┆ i64               ┆ str   ┆ datetime[μs, Asia/Tokyo]       │
# ╞═════════════════╪═══════════════════╪═══════╪════════════════════════════════╡
# │ 123456780       ┆ 9876543210        ┆ a:b:c ┆ 2023-03-25 10:56:59.663053 JST │
# │ 803065983       ┆ 2055938745        ┆ x:y:z ┆ 2023-03-25 12:38:18.050545 JST │
# └─────────────────┴───────────────────┴───────┴────────────────────────────────┘
```

title: feat(rust, python): thousand separators in shape of repr `DataFrame`

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body:
Resolves #7706.

Hello, I'm new to rust and contributions to open source. Thank you for the review!

I implemented this feature using the number formatting crate: https://docs.rs/num-format/latest/num_format/#
 - Appears for example as `shape: (100,000 x 200)`
 - Added formatting to series shape display, but left the comma `shape: (100,000,)`
 - Updated documentation via regex search - `shape: \((\d), (\d)\)` -> `shape: ($1 x $2)`

title: fix(python): raise error on attempt to set invalid `Datetime` or `Duration` dtype timeunit
body:
Somehow we missed having validation here; I made a small typo and it accepted it, leading to errors a little later. Minor update so we catch this up-front and raise a suitable ValueError.

```python
pl.Datetime("s")
# ValueError: Invalid time_unit; expected one of {'ns','us','ms'}, got 's'
```

title: fix(rust): compile issue in polars-lazy
body: polars-lazy would not compile with `--all-features` due to an issue with `is_first`.

title: fix(rust): compile issues in "polars-core" with default features
body:
`polars-core` would not compile independently without both `zip_with` and `sort_multiple` features enables. 

running these commands would result in compile issues.
```sh
> cd polars/polars-core
> cargo build
```

however this would work. 
```sh
> cargo build --features zip_with,sort_multiple
```

the `zip_with` was just missing a few `#[cfg(feature = "zip_with")]` statements.

However, the `sort_multiple` seems to be a core feature after the changes in  #7678. Since it is now a core part of the `sort` impl, it made sense to remove the feature flag all together.

title: feat(python): new "row_totals" parameter for `write_excel` that adds a row-wise total column using structured references

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body: Support adding one or more row-total columns to the output table. The total columns are written as Excel-native `SUM` formulae that use table-relative [structured references](https://www.ablebits.com/office-addins-blog/structured-references-excel-tables/), and support adjacent or disjoint column ranges. Integrates cleanly with `column_totals` (if also specified). ## Options * `row_totals = True` Sum all numeric columns into a "total" column. * `row_totals = {"colname": True}` Sum all numeric columns into a "colname" column. * `row_totals = {"colname": ("colx","coly")}` Sum only the given columns into a "colname" column; also allows for _more_ than one total column (as per the example below). ## Example ```python import polars as pl df = pl.DataFrame({ "id": ["aaa", "bbb", "ccc", "ddd", "eee"], "q1": [100, 55, -20, 0, 35], "q2": [30, -10, 15, 60, 20], "q3": [-50, 0, 40, 80, 80], "q4": [75, 55, 25, -10, -55], }) df.write_excel( table_style = "Table Style Light 2", dtype_formats = {pl.NUMERIC_DTYPES: "#,##0_);(#,##0)"}, sparklines = {"trend": ["q1", "q2", "q3", "q4"]}, row_totals = { # add semiannual row total columns "h1": ("q1","q2"), "h2": ("q3","q4"), }, column_totals = True, autofit = True, ) ``` ## Misc Optimisation Also in this update: * All format objects are now cached as they are generated/added into the workbook, such that there will only ever be _one_ format object with the given options - cols/ranges defining/applying the same format will now always reference the _same_ object. * Table data is now written column-wise instead of in one large block to improve some internal compatibility with formula columns.

title: docs(python): Add sort_by example taking one row per group
body: This PR adds an example to the `Expr.sort_by` docstring that shows how to take one row per group in a groupby where the minimum value of a column within that group is attained. I think this is probably a common use case and is worth highlighting since I had to search a little bit for how to achieve this. It's a natural extension of the use of `sort_by` from the previous example, so I think it fits nicely. Thanks for the great library btw :)

body: closes #7710

title: perf(rust, python): runtime SIMD target detection for `min/max/sum` and impl SIMD `mean` `~2-5x`
body:
Added runtime target cpu detection for SIMD accelerated min/max and sum kernels upstream in arrow2. This can double the perf as we compile the binary only for avx -> 128 bit registers. Whereas that specific function now also is compiled for avx2 -> 256 bit registers and at runtime dispatched.

Also implemented SIMD for `mean` aggregation. And added runtime dispatch. 

closes #7693

We are slightly slower than pyarrow here, because we are careful not to overflow:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3023000/226931488-bf977cf2-c919-42c2-87a9-2625ae740940.png)

title: fix(rust, python): Fix infering CSV schema when skip_rows_after_heade…

title: feat(python,rust): include `set_fmt_float` value in `Config` load/save state

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body:
Allow current state of the associated `Config.set_fmt_float` value to be saved; this also allows it to work properly in context-manager scope. 

(Also, declares a TypeAlias for FloatFmt and sorts some of the Config methods).

**Example:**
```python
with pl.Config() as cfg:
    cfg.set_fmt_float("full")
    print(df)

# float fmt reset to "mixed" (original state) on scope-exit
```

title: feat(python, rust): clearer error message when replace_time_zone encounters ambiguous or non-existent datetimes

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body:
This came up on discord

On master (shows neither the offending datetime, nor the offending time zone):
```python
In [91]: pl.Series(['2021-03-28 02:00']).str.strptime(pl.Datetime).dt.replace_time_zone('Europe/Warsaw')
thread '<unnamed>' panicked at 'No such local time', /root/.cargo/registry/src/index.crates.io-6f17d22bba15001f/chrono-0.4.23/src/offset/mod.rs:186:34
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

PanicException: No such local time
```

Here:
```python
In [1]: pl.Series(['2021-03-28 02:00']).str.strptime(pl.Datetime).dt.replace_time_zone('Europe/Warsaw')
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

ArrowErrorException: InvalidArgumentError("datetime '2021-03-28 02:00:00' is non-existent in time zone 'Europe/Warsaw'. Non-existent datetimes are not yet supported")
```

note: I've removed irrelevant parts of the traceback here for readability

title: docs(python): Remove duplicate column from Expr.sort example
body: A very minor documentation change - I noticed this duplication in one of the examples in the API reference for `polars.Expr.sort`.

title: fix(python): improve error message if unavailable lazy module is queried for `__version__` attribute
body:
Closes #7676.

Ensures that we raise the correct error when asking for the `__version__` attribute of unavailable lazy modules (eg: not installed in the host env/venv); now we'll get the expected `ModuleNotFound`, instead of some likely variant of `TypeError` (currently the version of an unavailable module is reported as `None`).

Relevant as we now check `__version__` in one or two places, so we'll benefit from raising the right error when the module isn't available; much more informative for the caller.

title: perf(rust, python): implement top-k optimization
body:
This implements a `top-k` for `DataFrame` (not exposed yet).

A `df.lazy().sort().head(100)` now gets optimized into a `top_k` call instead.

title: fix(python): fix reversed non-existant file error msg  (#7657)

Fixes #7657 

Note: Changed the `file_path` type from `String` to `&str`. Might also be solvable by iters. Thank you @Smebbs for your help!

title: refactor(python): Move `wrap_x` utils to `utils` module

labels.name: refactor

Partially addresses #7506 

Changes:
* Move `wrap_s`,  `wrap_expr`, `wrap_df`, and `wrap_ldf` to the `utils` module. Note that none of these functions are actually required for anything, they are just a nice shortcut for `DataFrame._from_pydf` or similar. _(`wrap_s` and `wrap_df` are actually used in the Rust bindings)_
* No longer export these utils through the `internals` module

Now the last step, to see if we can drop the core classes from being re-exported through `internals` :)

```python
df.select(

)
```

title: feat(python): add expression method equivalents for existing math/logical operators

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body:
Closes #4224.

* Adds equivalent method expressions for the remaining comparison/math operators...
  ```python
  # python operators
  df_op = df.select(
      a = pl.col(c1) == pl.col(c2),
      b = pl.col(c1) // pl.col(c2),
      c = pl.col(c1) >  pl.col(c2),
      d = pl.col(c1) >= pl.col(c2),
      e = pl.col(c1) <  pl.col(c2),
      f = pl.col(c1) <= pl.col(c2),
      g = pl.col(c1) %  pl.col(c2),
      h = pl.col(c1) != pl.col(c2),
      i = pl.col(c1) -  pl.col(c2),
      j = pl.col(c1) /  pl.col(c2),
      k = pl.col(c1) ^  pl.col(c2),
      l = pl.col(c1) *  pl.col(c2),
      m = pl.col(c1) ** pl.col(c2),
  )
  ```
  ```python
  # equivalent operator methods 
  df_expr = df.select(
      a = pl.col(c1).eq(pl.col(c2)),
      b = pl.col(c1).floordiv(pl.col(c2)),
      c = pl.col(c1).gt(pl.col(c2)),
      d = pl.col(c1).ge(pl.col(c2)),
      e = pl.col(c1).lt(pl.col(c2)),
      f = pl.col(c1).le(pl.col(c2)),
      g = pl.col(c1).mod(pl.col(c2)),
      h = pl.col(c1).ne(pl.col(c2)),
      i = pl.col(c1).sub(pl.col(c2)),
      j = pl.col(c1).truediv(pl.col(c2)),
      k = pl.col(c1).xor(pl.col(c2)),
      l = pl.col(c1).mul(pl.col(c2)),
      m = pl.col(c1).pow(pl.col(c2)),
  )
  ```
* ...and logical `and` / `or` (supporting *args, so you can splat or supply 'n' conditions):
  ```python
  # python operators
  df.select(
      all = (
          (pl.col("x") >= pl.col("z"))
          & (pl.col("y") >= pl.col("z"))
          & (pl.col("y") == pl.col("y"))
          & (pl.col("z") <= pl.col("x"))
          & (pl.col("y") != pl.col("x"))
      ),
      any = (
          (pl.col("x") == pl.col("y"))
          | (pl.col("x") == pl.col("y"))
          | (pl.col("y") == pl.col("z"))
          | (pl.col("y").cast(int) == pl.col("z"))
      )
  )
  ```
  
  ```python
  # equivalent "and"/"or" methods (mix and match ;)
  df.select(
      all = (pl.col("x") >= pl.col("z")).and_(
          pl.col("y") >= pl.col("z"),
          pl.col("y") == pl.col("y"),
          pl.col("z") <= pl.col("x"),
          pl.col("y") != pl.col("x"),
      ),
      any = (pl.col("x") == pl.col("y")).or_(
          pl.col("x") == pl.col("y"),
          pl.col("y") == pl.col("z"),
          pl.col("y").cast(int) == pl.col("z"),
      )
  )
  ```

title: perf(rust, python): use perfect hash table for ooc partitioning
fix(rust, python): fix schema of decimal type reads
body: fixes #7641

title: refactor(python): Eliminate function re-exports through `internals`

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Code improvements that do not change functionality

body:
Partially addresses #7506

Changes:
* Instead of using functions through `internals` (e.g. `pli.col`), import the functions module directly as `from polars import functions as F`, (e.g. `F.col`). This avoids a whole bunch of re-exports (indirection) through `internals`.

The `import functions as F` is pyspark-style, I thought it fit pretty well in our code base. Importing the functions directly (e.g. `from functions import col`) makes it hard to discern that `col` is in fact an imported function rather than a local variable.

`internals` is now close to being eradicated 😈 though of course those last few re-exports are hardest to solve

title: refactor(python): Move last functionality out of `internals`

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Code improvements that do not change functionality

body:
Partially addresses #7506

Changes:
* Move `deser_and_exec` and `construction` to the `utils` module.
* `internals` module no longer contains any functionality - changed the folder to a `internals.py` file which contains re-exports.

Next step will be to eliminate some re-exports - hopefully we can get that number to zero and get rid of the internals module entirely :)

```python
In [83]: pl.date_range(datetime(2021, 1, 1), datetime(2021, 1, 3), interval='d')
thread '<unnamed>' panicked at 'called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: ParseIntError { kind: Empty }', /home/runner/work/polars/polars/polars/polars-time/src/windows/duration.rs:110:59
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
PanicException                            Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In [83], line 1
----> 1 pl.date_range(datetime(2021, 1, 1), datetime(2021, 1, 3), interval='d')

File ~/tmp/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/polars/functions/eager.py:498, in date_range(low, high, interval, lazy, closed, name, time_unit, time_zone)
    495 start = _datetime_to_pl_timestamp(low, tu)
    496 stop = _datetime_to_pl_timestamp(high, tu)
    497 dt_range = pli.wrap_s(
--> 498     _py_date_range(start, stop, interval, closed, name, tu, time_zone)
    499 )
    500 if (
    501     low_is_date
    502     and high_is_date
    503     and not _interval_granularity(interval).endswith(("h", "m", "s"))
    504 ):
    505     dt_range = dt_range.cast(Date)

PanicException: called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: ParseIntError { kind: Empty }
```

title: fix(python): allow for list of datetimes with timezone(timedelta!=0) in Series constructor
body: closes #7644

title: fix(rust, python): respect time zone in rolling_* functions
feat(python): allow `scan_csv` to take a list of column names in a `new_columns` param

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or an improvement of an existing feature

body:
Closes: #7483.

Provides an easier way to assign column names to a headerless CSV file when using `scan_csv`, by automatically wrapping a sequence of names as a callable (as expected by the lower-level code), using the same "new_columns" parameter name found in `read_csv`.

**Before:**
```python
df = pl.scan_csv( 
    path_to_headerless_csv, 
    with_column_names = lambda cols: ["colx","coly","colz"],
)
```
**After:**
```python
df = pl.scan_csv( 
    path_to_headerless_csv, 
    new_columns = ["colx","coly","colz"],
)
```

labels.name: chore

body:
`apply_on_tz_corrected` isn't really necessary any more, the logic from https://github.com/pola-rs/polars/pull/7611 can be used in `truncate` too

If an [ambiguous](https://github.com/pola-rs/polars/issues/6672) argument were to be introduced, I think it'd be safer and more maintainable to have `truncate` and `round` go down the same path

title: fix(python): detect deltalake version in show_versions
body:
I noticed that we did not pick up the version of the optional deltalake dependency, as per https://github.com/delta-io/delta/issues/1339.

Solved this using importlib.metadata. This standard library function is not availble for Python 3.7, but I dont think it is worth adding the backport for that given Python 3.7 support may soon be dropped and there is no significant loss in functionality to end users.
